review.title: A Novel Method for Comparative Analysis of DNA Sequences by Ramanujan-Fourier Transform
review.abstract: Alignment-free sequence analysis approaches provide important alternatives over multiple sequence alignment (MSA) in biological sequence analysis because alignment-free approaches have low computation complexity and are not dependent on high level of sequence identity, however, most of the existing alignment-free methods do not employ true full information content of sequences and thus can not accurately reveal similarities and differences among DNA sequences. We present a novel alignment-free computational method for sequence analysis based on Ramanujan-Fourier transform (RFT), in which complete information of DNA sequences is retained. We represent DNA sequences as four binary indicator sequences and apply RFT on the indicator sequences to convert them into frequency domain. The Euclidean distance of the complete RFT coefficients of DNA sequences are used as similarity measure. To address the different lengths in Euclidean space of RFT coefficients, we pad zeros to short DNA binary sequences so that the binary sequences equal the longest length in the comparison sequence data. Thus, the DNA sequences are compared in the same dimensional frequency space without information loss. We demonstrate the usefulness of the proposed method by presenting experimental results on hierarchical clustering of genes and genomes. The proposed method opens a new channel to biological sequence analysis, classification, and structural module identification.

metadata.title: A Novel Method for Comparative Analysis of DNA Sequences by Ramanujan-Fourier Transform

sections.text: In biological sequence analysis, alignment-free sequence analysis approaches offer important alternatives over multiple sequence alignment (MSA) because alignment-free approaches have low computational complexity and are not dependent on a high level of sequence identity. However, most of the existing alignment-free methods do not use the full information content of the sequences and therefore cannot show precise similarities and differences between the DNA sequences. We present a novel alignment-free computation method for sequence analysis based on the Ramanujan Fourier Transformation (RFT), which preserves the complete information of the DNA sequences. We present DNA sequences as four binary indicator sequences and apply RFT to the indicator sequences to convert them into frequency domains. Euclidean removal of the complete RFT coefficients of the DNA sequences is used as a sequence measure to compare the different sequences in Euclidean classification with the short sequences proposed in hierarchical RFT.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Comparative analysis of DNA sequences is a fundamental task in genome research. Multiple Sequence Alignment (MSA) has assumed a key role in comparative structure and function analysis of biological sequences, but MSA has high computational complexity and depends on a high level of sequence algorithms. Several alignment-free sequence algorithms have been proposed to address the problems of MSA. These alignment-free methods can be divided into categories that include feature frequency profiles (FFP) (Sims et al., 2001), graphic theory (Qi et al., 2011), and analysis in frequency domains (Zhao et al., 2011). In these methods, feature extraction or transformation of a sequence may cause loss of information and may not reflect the actual similarities and differences between DNA sequences.

sections.heading: 2. Methods and Algorithms
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1. Representations of DNA sequences by binary indicators
sections.text: DNA molecules consist of four linearly linked nucleotides: adenine (A), thymine (T), cytosine (C) and guanine (G). A DNA sequence can be represented as a permutation of four characters A, T, C and G in different lengths. Before signal processing methods are applied to symbolic DNA sequences, the sequences are converted into numerical rows or binary indicator sequences (Voss, 1992). A DNA sequence designated as x (1), x (2),.., x (N) can be divided into four binary indicator sequences, uA (n), uT (n), uG (n) and uG (n), indicating the presence or absence of four nucleotides, A, T, C and G at the n − th position.

sections.heading: 2.2. Ramanujan-Fourier transform
sections.text: In signal processing, transformation methods are used to convert signals from period to frequency space, to estimate q = q = q = q functions (q = q functions) and to analyze the information content of the signal from various perspectives. Discrete Fourier Transformations (DFT) are generally applied to periodic or quasi-periodic signals, but this technique is not suitable for analyzing aperiodic random signals. As a result, numerous methods have been developed to analyze aperiodic time series with low frequencies (Planat et al., 2009; Planat et al., 2001).3The Ramanujan sums cq (n) are the real sums of the n − th power of the q − th power of the q − th roots of the unit (Ramanujan, 1918), cq = q functions.

sections.heading: 2.3. Discrete Fourier transform
sections.text: The discrete Fourier Transformation (DFT) is the transformation of N observation data (time domain) into N new values (frequency domain). DFT spectral analysis of DNA sequences could detect latent and hidden periodic signals in the original sequences (Strunk and Stoffer, 2010). It could detect approximate repetitions difficult to detect by direct tandem repeat searches. Let UA, UT, UC and UG define the DFT of the binary sequences uA, uT, uC and uG, 6the DFT of the numerical series uα, α {A, T, C, G} of length N as Uα (k) = N ∑ n = 1uα (n) e − i 2π N kn (14), where i = √ − 1. The DFT power spectrum of the signal uα at frequency k is asPS (k) = relative inactivity.

sections.heading: 2.4. Distance metrics
sections.text: A distance metric d (x, y) is a non-negative function in the set of pairs (x, y) of finite sequences across a specified alphabet. For example, one of its applications is a measure of the evolutionary change from DNA sequence x to y. The evolutionary changes are reversible, and the least number of evolutionary changes is from x to y. Therefore, a distance metric should be reflective, symmetrical and transitive (Waterman, 1976; Kanas and Lecko, 1991; Otu and Sayood, 2003). A metric space is a set of X along with a metric d on it. The set of real numbers with the function d (x, y) = | x − y | is a metric space. A distance metric in metric space fulfills the following properties (1) d (x, y).

sections.heading: 2.5. Algorithm to compute pairwise distance of DNA sequences by RFT
sections.text: From the above definitions and theories, we propose the following algorithm to calculate pairs of Euclidean distances as distance measurements of DNA sequences using RFT, which is used to construct similarity matrices for phylogenetic trees.Data: DNA SEQ1 (length N1), SEQ2 (length N2), SEQ3 (length M), with M > N1 and M > N2 result: pair removal of SEQ1, SEQ2 and SEQ3 step1. Convert each SEQ1, SEQ2, SEQ3 into four binary indicator sequences BS1, BS2 and BS3.2. Add zeros to BS1 and BS2 to extend their lengths to M and become BS1M, BS2M, and SQ3, respectively. 3. Calculate the RFT coefficients of BS1M, BS2M and BS3.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.text: In fact, most of the cases mentioned are a conspiracy that has occurred in the past.

sections.heading: 3.3. Application of the RFT distance metric in construction of phylogenetic trees
sections.text: In fact, we are in a position to go in search of a solution that will enable us to go in search of a solution that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to, that will enable us to.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this work, we have established an effective similarity measurement of DNA sequences based on RFT. First, we performed RFT on DNA sequences after converting symbolic sequences into four binary indicator sequences. Euclidean removal is used to calculate the similarity of RFT coefficients. We performed various DNA sequence mutants and evaluated the accuracy of the new RFT metric on the mutants. Similarity metrics were evaluated by constructing phylogenetic virus trees at the gene level. Our work offers encouraging steps towards applying the rediscovered RFT approach for effective comparative studies of biological sequences.

sections.text: We thank Xuemeng E. Yin of William Fremd High School, IL, USA, for proofreading the essay.

Ramanujan sums (RS) are named after Indian mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan, who in 1918 introduced them and proved Vinogradov’s theorem that every sufficiently large odd number is the sum of three primes (Ramanujan, 1918).

metadata.abstractText: Alignment-free sequence analysis approaches provide important alternatives over multiple sequence alignment (MSA) in biological sequence analysis because alignment-free approaches have low computation complexity and are not dependent on high level of sequence identity, however, most of the existing alignment-free methods do not employ true full information content of sequences and thus can not accurately reveal similarities and differences among DNA sequences. We present a novel alignment-free computational method for sequence analysis based on Ramanujan-Fourier transform (RFT), in which complete information of DNA sequences is retained. We represent DNA sequences as four binary indicator sequences and apply RFT on the indicator sequences to convert them into frequency domain. The Euclidean distance of the complete RFT coefficients of DNA sequences are used as similarity measure. To address the different lengths in Euclidean space of RFT coefficients, we pad zeros to short DNA binary sequences so that the binary sequences equal the longest length in the comparison sequence data. Thus, the DNA sequences are compared in the same dimensional frequency space without information loss. We demonstrate the usefulness of the proposed method by presenting experimental results on hierarchical clustering of genes and genomes. The proposed method opens a new channel to biological sequence analysis, classification, and structural module identification.
